item.title: Race Is On to Detect Ebola Faster
item.description: Companies, government agencies and nonprofits are taking steps to speed development of diagnostics that can detect Ebola sooner after infection and deliver results more quickly after a sample is taken.

item.title: More Health-Site Bugs Loom
item.description: Technology gaps in HealthCare.gov are expected to cause consumers and insurers a fresh batch of complications after the site reopens for health-plan enrollment this month, insurance-industry officials say.

item.title: Ebola Crisis Offers Lessons, Warnings on Epidemics, Gates Says
item.description: The billionaire philanthropist says there are many lessons to be learned from the Ebola epidemic raging in West Africa. The biggest, he says, is that the world has far to go before it is prepared to combat an even-larger disease threat.

item.title: Hospital Records Adapt to Flag Ebola
item.description: Five days after the first U.S. Ebola case was confirmed, Massachusetts General deployed a new Ebola application that automatically matches a patient’s travel and family history with medical symptoms.

item.title: U.S. Ebola Survivors Tread Lonely Journeys
item.description: The experiences of people who have been treated trace the splintered path of Ebola in America.

item.title: Researchers Study Ebola Link to Gene in Rare Disease
item.description: In the search for answers about Ebola, researchers are starting to look at an unexpected group of people: parents with children who have the fatal genetic disease Niemann-Pick Type C.

item.title: New Jersey Details Ebola Policy
item.description: New Jersey officials spelled out the state’s quarantine policy, which has been criticized by some health officials but is popular among the public.

item.title: Our Ancestors Murdered---and Played Nice
item.description: Given chimps’ murderous tendencies, are we doomed to be violent? Robert M. Sapolsky says the planet of the apes is more complicated than you’d think.

item.title: Eat Breakfast and Remember the Protein, Scientists Say
item.description: New research underlines the need to eat breakfast, particularly one rich in protein.

item.title: Plan for Uncontrolled Ebola Trial Draws Fire
item.description: Medical groups in the U.K. and France say that it would be unethical to hold back experimental Ebola treatments from anyone. U.S. officials say that without control groups getting placebos, it can’t be known whether the drugs are saving lives or killing people.

item.title: Maine Nurse Resists Ebola Quarantine
item.description: Kaci Hickox, the Maine nurse who traveled to West Africa to care for Ebola patients, said that she won’t self-quarantine for 21 days, setting up a possible legal battle with the state.

item.title: Hagel Approves 21-Day Ebola Isolation Period For Military
item.description: U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel approved a recommendation from the Joint Chiefs of Staff requiring a 21-day isolation period for all military personnel returning from West Africa.

item.title: New Jersey Hospitals in Spotlight
item.description: The experience of a nurse who complained about her quarantine in a makeshift tent inside a Newark, N.J., hospital after treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone is putting a focus on how the state’s hospitals will handle those exposed to the disease.

item.title: CDC Rejects Mandatory Ebola Quarantines
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control recommended that people deemed to be at high risk of developing Ebola voluntarily isolate themselves from others for 21 days, but stopped short of recommending the mandatory quarantines that at least two states have ordered.

item.title: Muscular Dystrophy Drug Suffers Setback
item.description: Sarepta Therapeutics said it would be delayed at least six months in seeking approval for its muscular-dystrophy drug after the FDA demanded more information because of concerns over the clinical-trial data.

item.title: White House Pushes Back On State Ebola Quarantines
item.description: The White House pushed back against the governors of New York, New Jersey, Illinois and other states that instituted procedures to forcibly quarantine medical workers returning from West Africa, deepening a debate brought on by recent Ebola cases in the U.S.

item.title: FDA Approves Two Faster Ebola Tests
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration on Saturday authorized use of two new diagnostic tests for Ebola that can produce results in two hours, compared with what can usually take four hours.

item.title: CDC Responds Rapidly to Latest Ebola Case
item.description: The federal and state response to an infected doctor in New York presents a sharp contrast to the response to the nation’s first case in Dallas late last month.

item.title: State Quarantines Stoke Debate Over Monitoring
item.description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut imposed 21-day quarantines on health-care workers returning from West Africa, stoking a debate over how to curb Ebola without impeding humanitarian aid.

item.title: New York Officials Urge Calm Amid Ebola Diagnosis
item.description: New York Gov. Cuomo said he planned to ride all of the subway lines used by a 33-year-old physician who has been diagnosed with Ebola after returning from Guinea.

item.title: Bellevue Was Ready to Go on Ebola
item.description: A Bellevue isolation ward developed during the dawn of the AIDS crisis has been repurposed, in part, by health officials as the go-to treatment facility for New York-based Ebola patients.

item.title: Ebola Puts Spotlight on Bellevue Hospital
item.description: The first Ebola case in New York turns the spotlight on the city’s marquee trauma center, which will be tested with containing the disease in one of the country’s most crowded urban areas.

item.title: New York Officials Tracing Movements of Ebola Patient
item.description: New York City officials said they are retracing the steps of Craig Spencer, the doctor who was diagnosed with Ebola, even as they assured New Yorkers they had little to fear about the spread of the disease.

item.title: Lawmakers Seek Greater Bio-Research Funding
item.description: A bipartisan pair of senators is putting together a proposal to significantly increase federal funding for biomedical research, an issue that has taken on greater urgency in light of the Ebola outbreak.

item.title: Ebola Survivors' Blood to Be Studied as Treatment
item.description: Researchers plan to test the effectiveness of transfusing blood products from Ebola survivors into infected patients, as a potential near-term countermeasure to the outbreak in West Africa.
